title: Credit debt accrued during marriage however in collections currently; debt relief program. Ex responsible too? my name only
question: In divorce; Joint credit debt in my name only during marriage. currently using debt relief program to negotiate paying without interest; damaged my credit. Even though it is considered "charged off" is Ex still responsible for this debt? If so will judge likely order him to assist in making payments or take over portion of debt from my name? Thank you in advance!
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: If you are actually paying the debt, then he should equally share in the obligation if it is community debt.

The debt described appears to be a community debt as defined by California Family Code section 910 and California Family Code section 2620. If you pay off part or all of the debt, the court can require your "Ex" to reimburse you for one-half of the payments you make. If you get the debt reduced, then he would most likely get the benefit of one-half of that reduction. A court can order one of the parties, including your ex, to make all the payments on a debt; but then there would have to be an equalization somewhere on your part because you owe one-half as well. I don't believe that you have any recourse against your "Ex" for damaged credit but you might want to get ahold of the credit reporting agencies and ask they include an explanation of why the debts were not paid. Good luck.

If the debt was a community property liability, it should be included in your financial schedules, and it should be included in the division of assets and debts.

As to the debt settlement program, a majority of these programs are scams, and your ex may not be responsible for the money that you waste on the program.

Consumer debts that are incurred during a marriage are considered joint debts owed by both spouses. If a credit card was used for business expenses as opposed to personal and household expenses, the other spouse might argue that he is not responsible for the business expenses of the ex spouse.

If a debt was charged-off, that only means that the creditor closed the account and is no longer directly involved in trying to get paid; however, the creditor can hire a debt collector or debt collection attorney to pursue the debt. Whether a court might order your ex to pay part of the debt is a question for your divorce attorney. There are a lot of factors that go into how property and debts are divided in a divorce.
